articles.headline: Two Studios to Support HD DVD Over Rival
articles.snippet: Paramount and DreamWorks Animation said they would exclusively back the HD DVD format for the release of high-definition movies on disc.
articles.abstract: Paramount and DreamWorks Animation said they would exclusively back the HD DVD format for the release of high-definition movies on disc.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 — Hollywood’s squabble over which of two technologies will replace standard DVDs reignited Monday with two studios throwing their weight behind one format and several rivals ramping up support for the other.

articles.headline: Plaintiffs Find Payday Elusive in Vioxx Cases
articles.snippet: No one who has sued Merck over heart attacks or strokes suffered after taking Vioxx has received payments.
articles.abstract: No one who has sued Merck over heart attacks or strokes suffered after taking Vioxx has received payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEENE, Tex. — In Carol Ernst’s eyes, two years ago she won a measure of justice.

articles.headline: A Fear of Foreign Investments
articles.snippet: At a time of global financial instability, the Bush administration has started to worry that funds held by foreign governments could destabilize markets.
articles.abstract: At a time of global financial instability, the Bush administration has started to worry that funds held by foreign governments could destabilize markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 — For years, the Bush administration has shrugged off concerns about the trillions of dollars that the United States owes to China, Japan and oil-producing countries in the Middle East, arguing that these debts give no undue leverage to foreign governments.

articles.headline: Can Private Equity Firms Get Out of Buyouts?
articles.snippet: Amid the ever-tightening market for corporate debt, investors are already betting that some of the biggest deals may collapse, or at least be renegotiated.
articles.abstract: Amid the ever-tightening market for corporate debt, investors are already betting that some of the biggest deals may collapse, or at least be renegotiated.

articles.headline: 2005 Incomes, on Average, Still Below 2000 Peak
articles.snippet: The average income in 2005 was $55,238, nearly 1 percent less than the $55,714 in 2000, after adjusting for inflation.
articles.abstract: The average income in 2005 was $55,238, nearly 1 percent less than the $55,714 in 2000, after adjusting for inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans earned a smaller average income in 2005 than in 2000, the fifth consecutive year that they had to make ends meet with less money than at the peak of the last economic expansion, new government data shows.

articles.headline: Investors, on Edge, Grab Up Treasury Bills
articles.snippet: In a sign that investors are fleeing investments that carry even the slightest hint of risk, the price of short-term government debt soared Monday.
articles.abstract: In a sign that investors are fleeing investments that carry even the slightest hint of risk, the price of short-term government debt soared Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market was quiet yesterday, but debt markets were anything but.

articles.headline: Yes, Deep-Fried Oreos, but Not in Trans Fats
articles.snippet: The leaders of the Great Indiana State Fair have banned oils with trans fats from all its fryers.
articles.abstract: The leaders of the Great Indiana State Fair have banned oils with trans fats from all its fryers.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 — The deep-fried Combo Plate may be a little more healthful this year at the Great Indiana State Fair. So say the fair’s leaders, who, taking a step rarely seen in the realm of corn dogs and fried pickles, have banned oils with trans fats from all the fryers that line the grounds here.

articles.headline: China’s Trade in Africa Carries a Price Tag
articles.snippet: Manufacturing has suffered in Africa as cheap Chinese goods flood the market, eliminating needed jobs.
articles.abstract: Manufacturing has suffered in Africa as cheap Chinese goods flood the market, eliminating needed jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABWE, Zambia — The courtyard in front of the Zambia China Mulungushi Textiles factory is so quiet, even at midday, that the fluttering of the ragged Chinese and Zambian flags is the only sound hanging in the air.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Howard W. French
